element.name: email_confirm
element.documentation: We have two MRI scans for the patient we are processing: before and after the sEEG implantation. The second one shows artifacts around the contacts of the depth electrodes and can be used to identify their positions. In order to use the volumes simultaneously, we use SPM to register them together, then normalize them to the MNI space.

element.name: Electrode positions
element.documentation: In order to generate epileptogenicity maps, we need accurate 3D positions for the contacts of the depth electrodes. There are various solutions to get these positions, the best one depending on the information you have access to and the type of material that was implanted. Placing the contacts requires a good understanding of the implantation scheme reported by the neurosurgeon, and some skills in reading MRI scans.

element.name: Registered pre-implantation MRI, defaced, normalized in MNI space
Registered post-implantation MRI, defaced, normalized in MNI space
Deformation fields from subject space to MNI space (pre-implentation MRI)
Deformation fields from subject space to MNI space (post-implentation MRI)
ImaGIN 2
element.documentation:
https://f-tract.eu/software/imagin/

Instructions:

  • Download zip: https://gin11-git.ujf-grenoble.fr/ftract_dev/ImaGIN2/tree/master/
  • Unzip on your computer, rename to "ImaGIN2"
  • Start MATLAB, go to the ImaGIN2 folder
  • Run script: ImaGIN.m

element.name: Electrode positions with Brainstorm
element.documentation: The online tutorial SEEG epileptogenicity maps explains how to import and process SEEG recordings with Brainstorm. You can use the information on this page to create a text file with the position of all the SEEG contacts, that you can import with ImaGIN. Start by importing the pre- and post-implantation volumes to your Brainstorm database (Import the anatomy), then create a new implantation file (Edit the contacts positions) and finally use the menu "Contacts > Export contacts positions".

element.name: Seizure recordings converted in SPM format

node.label: Workflow – electrodes identification1) Open terminal2) Type “fsl”3) Click FLIRT linear registration4) Click Reference Image – and choose the T1 image of your patient5) Click MODEL/DOF and change to Rigid Body6) Click Input image – and show the path to your a) Bone_CT_image7) Click Output image – and show the same path as for the Input but change the name of the file, example if the file was called Bone_CT_image_xxxx.nii.gz call it coreg_Bone_CT_image_xxxx.nii.gzi) The reference image stays the sameii) xxxx is the name of the subject8) Click advanced Options and change in Cost Function to Mutual Information. Do not change other options. Press Go9) Click Input image – and show the path to your a) Post-implantation_CT_image10) Click Output image – and show the same path as for the Input but change the name of the file, example if the file was called Post-implantation_CT_image_xxxx.nii.gz call it coreg_Post-implantation_CT_image.nii.gz i) The reference image stays the same ii) xxxx is the name of the subject11) Click advanced Options and change in Cost Function to Mutual Information. Do not change other options. Press Go12) In terminal use fslmaths option to subtract electrodes position from coreg_Post-implantation_CT_image.nii.gz and coreg_ Bone_CT_image_xxxx.nii.gz. Use the formula fslmaths coreg_Post-implantation_CT_image.nii.gz –sub coreg_Bone_CT_image_xxxx.nii.gz post_implatation_xxxx.nii.gzThis file contained the position of electrodes without the bone and brain tissue.13) In terminal -Threshold the obtained post_implatation_xxxx.nii.gz file bu using the formula fslmaths post_implatation_xxxx.nii.gz-thr 1500 electrodes_xxxx.nii.gzi) Note that you should use variable thresholds to find your optimum – between 1000 to 2000, depending on the quality of your data14) Check the position of your electrodes by typing in the terminal fsl, than click on FSLeyesa) Load your Post-implantation_CT_image and superimpose the electrodes_xxxx.nii.gz to check if your electrodes are well visible
